NOTE: An official document number may be assigned to uniquely identify the legislative instrument.
EXAMPLE: CELEX Number used to uniquely identify European Union Legislation

FeatureAttribute.name: dateEnteredIntoForce
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date the legislative instrument entered into force.

FeatureAttribute.name: dateRepealed
FeatureAttribute.definition: Date the legislative instrument was repealed.

FeatureAttribute.name: level
FeatureAttribute.definition: The level at which the legislative instrument is adopted.

FeatureAttribute.name: journalCitation
FeatureAttribute.definition: Citation of the official journal in which the legislation is published.

FeatureType.name: LegislationLevelValue
FeatureType.definition: The level at which a legal act or convention has been adopted.

FeatureAttribute.name: international
FeatureAttribute.definition: An international legal act or convention.

FeatureAttribute.name: european
FeatureAttribute.definition: A legal act of the European Union.

FeatureAttribute.name: national
FeatureAttribute.definition: A legal act at national level.

FeatureAttribute.name: sub-national
FeatureAttribute.definition: A legal act at sub-national level.
NOTE The sub-national level encompasses both regional or local legislative instruments.

FeatureType.name: OfficialJournalInformation
FeatureType.definition: Full citation of the location of the legislative instrument within the official journal.

FeatureAttribute.name: officialJournalIdentification
FeatureAttribute.definition: Reference to the location within the official journal within which the legislative instrument was published. This reference shall be comprised of three parts:
- the title of the official journal
EXAMPLE: Official Journal of European Union (OJEU), L108, Volume 50, 1-14

FeatureAttribute.name: ISSN
FeatureAttribute.definition: The International Standard Serial Number (ISSN) is an eight-digit number that identifies the periodical publication in which the legislative instrument was published.
NOTE: Periodical publilcations are issued in successive parts, usually having numerical or chronological designations and required that each serial publication can be uniquely identified.
EXAMPLE: OJ Series in which INSPIRE Directive is published has been assigned the ISSN: 1725-2555

FeatureAttribute.name: ISBN
FeatureAttribute.definition: International Standard Book Number (ISBN) is an nine-digit number that uniquely identifies the book in which the legislative instrument was published.

FeatureAttribute.name: linkToJournal
FeatureAttribute.definition: Link to an online version of the official journal

FeatureType.name: PartyRoleValue
FeatureType.definition: Roles of parties related to or responsible for a resource.

FeatureType.name: RelatedParty
FeatureType.definition: An organisation or a person with a role related to a resource.
NOTE 1 A party, typically an individual person, acting as a general point of contact for a resource can be specified without providing any particular role.

constraint.name: individual, organisation or position name shall be provided
constraint.description: At least the individual, organisation or position name shall be provided.
constraint.expression: inv: individualName->notEmpty() or organisationName->notEmpty() or positionName->notEmpty()

FeatureAttribute.name: positionName
FeatureAttribute.definition: Position of the party in relation to a resource, such as head of department.

FeatureAttribute.name: contact
FeatureAttribute.definition: Contact information for the related party.

FeatureAttribute.name: role
FeatureAttribute.definition: Role(s) of the party in relation to a resource, such as owner.

FeatureType.name: ThematicIdentifier
FeatureType.definition: Thematic identifier to uniquely identify the spatial object.
Some spatial objects may be assigned multiple unique identifiers.
These may have been established to meet data exchange requirements of different reporting obligations at International, European or national levels and/or internal data maintenance requirements.

FeatureAttribute.name: identifier
FeatureAttribute.definition: Unique identifier used to identify the spatial object within the specified identification scheme.

FeatureAttribute.name: identifierScheme
FeatureAttribute.definition: Identifier defining the scheme used to assign the identifier.
NOTE 1: Reporting requirements for different environmental legislation mandate that each spatial object is assigned an identifier conforming to specific lexical rules.
NOTE 2: These rules are often inconsistent so a spatial object may be assigned multiple identifiers which are used for object referencing to link information to the spatial object.

FeatureType.name: ThemeValue
FeatureType.definition: grouping of spatial data according to Annex I, II and III of the INSPIRE Directive

FeatureAttribute.name: AM
FeatureAttribute.definition: Area management/restriction/regulation zones and reporting units

Value.label: fromFeature
Value.definition: Derived automatically from another INSPIRE spatial object which is related to the address or address component.
NOTE This method implies that the position is calculated automatically e.g. as a centre point of the polygon or linestring that describes the feature in question.
EXAMPLE Geometries can be derived from a building, cadastral parcel, thoroughfare link, address area (named place) or administrative unit.

Value.label: byAdministrator
Value.definition: Decided and recorded manually by the official body responsible for address allocation or by the dataset custodian.

Value.label: byOtherParty
Value.definition: Decided and recorded manually by other party.

Value.label: siteLevel
Value.definition: The locator identifies a specific plot of land, building or similar property by use of an address number, building number, building or property name.

Value.label: accessLevel
Value.definition: The locator identifies a specific access to a plot of land, building or similar by use of an entrance number or similar identifier.

Value.label: unitLevel
Value.definition: The locator identifies a specific part of a building.
EXAMPLE The unit level can be, e.g., a dwelling, flat, apartment, room or household, inside a building by use of for example staircase identifier, floor identifier and/or unit number, name.

Value.label: postalDeliveryPoint
Value.definition: The locator identifies a postal delivery point.
EXAMPLE Postal delivery point can be, e.g., a P.O. box, a private bag, a business reply mail or a large volume receiver.

Value.label: addressIdentifierGeneral
Value.definition: Address identifier composed by numbers and/or characters.

Value.label: addressNumber
Value.definition: Address identifier composed only by numbers.

Value.label: addressNumberExtension
Value.definition: EXAMPLE E.g., in the Czech Republic a new address situated between two old addresses with numbers "2" and "3" receives a number "2" with an extension "a" so the full address number becomes "2a".

Value.label: addressNumber2ndExtension
Value.definition: Second extension to the address number.

Value.label: buildingIdentifier
Value.definition: Building identifier composed by numbers and/or characters.

Value.label: buildingIdentifierPrefix
Value.definition: EXAMPLE In the Czech Republic the building numbers can have prefix to distinguish between two types of buildings: "c. p." (descriptive number) for buildings of permanent character and "c. evid." (registration number) for temporary dwelling (e.g. holiday cottagesand garages).

Value.label: entranceDoorIdentifier
Value.definition: Identifier for an entrance door, gate, or port.

Value.label: staircaseIdentifier
Value.definition: Identifier for a staircase, normally inside a building.

Value.label: floorIdentifier
Value.definition: Identifier of a floor or level inside a building.

Value.label: unitIdentifier
Value.definition: Identifier of a door, dwelling, suite or room inside a building.

Value.label: postalDeliveryIdentifier
Value.definition: Identifier of a postal delivery point.
EXAMPLE A Post office box (P.O. box).

Value.label: kilometrePoint
Value.definition: A mark on a road whose number identifies the existing distance between the origin point of the road and that mark, measured along the road.

Value.label: cornerAddress1stIdentifier
Value.definition: Address identifier related to the primary thoroughfare name in a corner address.
NOTE The concept of corner addresses with a primary and secondary thoroughfare name, each with an address identifier. Is used, e.g. in Lithuania and Estonia.

Value.label: cornerAddress2ndIdentifier
Value.definition: Address identifier related to the secondary thoroughfare name in a corner address.
NOTE The concept of corner addresses with a primary and secondary thoroughfare name, each with an address identifier. Is used, e.g. in Lithuania and Estonia.

Value.label: current
Value.definition: Current and valid address according to official body responsible for address allocation or deemed, by the dataset custodian, to be the most appropriate, commonly used address.

Value.label: retired
Value.definition: An address no longer in every day use or abolished by the official body responsible for address allocation or by the dataset custodian.

Value.label: proposed
Value.definition: An address awaiting approval by the dataset custodian or official body responsible for address allocation.

Value.label: reserved
Value.definition: An address approved by the by the official body responsible for address allocation or by the dataset custodian, but yet to be implemented.

Value.label: alternative
Value.definition: An address in common use but different from the master address as determined by the official body responsible for address allocation or by the dataset custodian.

Value.label: postalDelivery
Value.definition: Position aims at identifying a postal delivery point.

Value.label: utilityService
Value.definition: Position aims at identifying a point of utility service.

Value.label: thoroughfareAccess
Value.definition: Position aims at identifying the access point from the thoroughfare.

Value.label: entrance
Value.definition: Position aims at identifying the entrance door or gate.

Value.label: building
Value.definition: Position aims at identifying the related building.

Value.label: parcel
Value.definition: Position aims at identifying the related land parcel.

Value.label: segment
Value.definition: Position derived from the related segment of a thoroughfare.

Value.label: postalDescriptor
Value.definition: Position derived from the related postcode area.

Value.label: addressArea
Value.definition: Position derived from the related address area.

Value.label: adminUnit1stOrder
Value.definition: Position derived from the related administrative unit of 1st order.

Value.label: adminUnit2ndOrder
Value.definition: Position derived from the related administrative unit of 2nd order.

Value.label: adminUnit3rdOrder
Value.definition: Position derived from the related administrative unit of 3rd order.

Value.label: adminUnit4thOrder
Value.definition: Position derived from the related administrative unit of 4th order.

Value.label: adminUnit5thOrder
Value.definition: Position derived from the related administrative unit of 5th order.

Value.label: adminUnit6thOrder
Value.definition: Position derived from the related administrative unit of 6th order.

Value.label: name
Value.definition: The part of name constitutes the core or root of the thoroughfare name.

EXAMPLE "Abelheira" in Rua da Abelheira (Caçém, Portugal), "Madeleine" in Place de la Madeleine (Paris, France), "Christo Canneregio" in Calle del Christo Canneregio (Venezia, Italy), "Quai" in Unterer Quai (Biel/Bienne, Switzerland) and "Strand" in Little Strand Street (Dublin, Ireland).

Value.label: namePrefix
Value.definition: The part of name is used to separate connecting words without sorting significance from the core of the thoroughfare name.
EXAMPLE "da" in Rua da Abelheira (Caçém, Portugal), "de la " in Place de la Madeleine (Paris, France) and "del" in Calle del Christo Canneregio (Venezia, Italy).

Value.label: type
Value.definition: The part of name indicates the category or type of thoroughfare.

EXAMPLE "Rua" in Rua da Abelheira (Caçém, Portugal), "Place" in Place de la Madeleine (Paris, France), "Calle" in Calle del Christo Canneregio (Venezia, Italy) and "Street" in Little Strand Street (Dublin, Ireland).

Value.label: qualifier
Value.definition: The part of name qualifies the thoroughfare name.
EXAMPLE "Unterer" in Unterer Quai (German name in Biel/Bienne, Switzerland), "Bas" in Quai Bas (French name for same street) and "Little" in Little Strand Street (Dublin, Ireland).

Value.label: siteName
Value.definition: Name of real estate, building complex or site.
EXAMPLE The name of a manor, shopping mall or university campus.

Value.label: buildingName
Value.definition: Name of building or part of building.

Value.label: roomName
Value.definition: Identifier of a dwelling, suite or room inside a building.

Value.label: descriptiveLocator
Value.definition: Narrative, textual description of the location or addressable object.

Value.label: edgeMatched
Value.definition: The boundaries of neighbouring administrative units have the same set of coordinates.

Value.label: notEdgeMatched
Value.definition: The boundaries of neighbouring administrative units do not have the same set of coordinates.

Value.label: 1stOrder
Value.definition: Highest level in the national administrative hierarchy (country level).

Value.label: 2ndOrder
Value.definition: 2nd level in the national administrative hierarchy.

Value.label: 3rdOrder
Value.definition: 3rd level in the national administrative hierarchy.

Value.label: 4thOrder
Value.definition: 4th level in the national administrative hierarchy.

Value.label: 5thOrder
Value.definition: 5th level in the national administrative hierarchy.

Value.label: 6thOrder
Value.definition: 6th level in the national administrative hierarchy.

Value.label: agreed
Value.definition: The edge-matched boundary has been agreed between neighbouring administrative units and is stable now.

Value.label: notAgreed
Value.definition: The edge-matched boundary has not yet been agreed between neighbouring administrative units and could be changed.

Value.label: contiguousZone
Value.definition: A zone contiguous to a territorial sea of a coastal State, which may not extend beyond 24 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured.
NOTE 1 The contiguous zone is adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State.

NOTE 2 In the contiguous zone a coastal State may exercise the control necessary to prevent and punish infringements of its customs, fiscal, immigration, or sanitary laws and regulations within its territory or territorial sea. See also Article 33 of United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Value.label: continentalShelf
Value.definition: A maritime zone beyond and adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State whose outer boundary is determined in accordance with Article 76 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
NOTE 1 The continental shelf is adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State. The continental shelf overlaps with the extent of contiguous zone and exclusive economic zone of a coastal State.
NOTE 2 Art. 76 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea:

1. The continental shelf of a coastal State comprises the seabed and subsoil of the submarine areas that extend beyond its territorial sea throughout the natural prolongation of its land territory to the outer edge of the continental margin, or to a distance of 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured where the outer edge of the continental margin does not extend up to that distance.
2. The continental shelf of a coastal State shall not extend beyond the limits provided for in paragraphs 4 to 6.

3. The continental margin comprises the submerged prolongation of the land mass of the coastal State, and consists of the seabed and subsoil of the shelf, the slope and the rise. It does not include the deep ocean floor with its oceanic ridges or the subsoil thereof.

4. (a) For the purposes of this Convention, the coastal State shall establish the outer edge of the continental margin wherever the margin extends beyond 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured, by either:

(i) a line delineated in accordance with paragraph 7 by reference to the outermost fixed points at each of which the thickness of sedimentary rocks is at least 1 per cent of the shortest distance from such point to the foot of the continental slope; or
(ii) a line delineated in accordance with paragraph 7 by reference to fixed points not more than 60 nautical miles from the foot of the continental slope.
(b) In the absence of evidence to the contrary, the foot of the continental slope shall be determined as the point of maximum change in the gradient at its base.

5. The fixed points comprising the line of the outer limits of the continental shelf on the seabed, drawn in accordance with paragraph 4 (a)(i) and (ii), either shall not exceed 350 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured or shall not exceed 100 nautical miles from the 2,500 metre isobath, which is a line connecting the depth of 2,500 metres.

6. Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph 5, on submarine ridges, the outer limit of the continental shelf shall not exceed 350 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured. This paragraph does not apply to submarine elevations that are natural components of the continental margin, such as its plateaux, rises, caps, banks and spurs.

7. The coastal State shall delineate the outer limits of its continental shelf, where that shelf extends beyond 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured, by straight lines not exceeding 60 nautical miles in length, connecting fixed points, defined by coordinates of latitude and longitude.

8. Information on the limits of the continental shelf beyond 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the territorial sea is measured shall be submitted by the coastal State to the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf set up under Annex II on the basis of equitable geographical representation. The Commission shall make recommendations to coastal States on matters related to the establishment of the outer limits of their continental shelf. The limits of the shelf established by a coastal State on the basis of these recommendations shall be final and binding.

9. The coastal State shall deposit with the Secretary-General of the United Nations charts and relevant information, including geodetic data, permanently describing the outer limits of its continental shelf. The Secretary-General shall give due publicity thereto.
10. The provisions of this article are without prejudice to the question of delimitation of the continental shelf between States with opposite or adjacent coasts.

Value.label: exclusiveEconomicZone
Value.definition: An area beyond and adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State, subject to the specific legal regime under which the rights and jurisdiction of the coastal State and the rights and freedoms of other States are governed by the relevant provisions of the United Nations Convention on Law of the Sea.
SOURCE Article 55 of United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
NOTE 1 The exclusive economic zone is adjacent to the territorial sea of a coastal State. Exclusive economic zone overlaps with the extent of contiguous zone of a coastal State.

NOTE 2 Under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), the coastal States are entitled to an exclusive economic zone extending no further than 200 nautical miles from the baselines from which the breadth of the Member State's territorial sea is measured.

NOTE 3 In contrast to the continental shelf, an exclusive economic zone must be explicitly proclaimed or installed by the coastal state and includes, besides the seabed and its subsoil, the waters super-adjacent to the seabed.

Value.label: internalWaters
Value.definition: The waters on the landward side of the baselines of the territorial sea of the coastal State.
SOURCE Article 5 of United Nations Convention of Law on the Sea.

NOTE 1 The internal waters is the zone between the shoreline and the baseline (see the Data Specification for "Sea Regions” INSPIRE theme). The delineation of the landward boundary of the internal waters is regulated differently in different countries.
NOTE 2 The internal waters can include waterways, mouths of the rivers and bays.

Value.label: territorialSea
Value.definition: A belt of sea of a defined breadth not exceeding 12 nautical miles measured from the baselines determined in accordance to the United Nations Convention of Law on the Sea.
SOURCE IHO Dictionary, S-32, Fifth Edition.

NOTE The sovereignty of a coastal State extends, beyond its land territory and internal waters and, in the case of an archipelagic State, its archipelagic waters, to an adjacent belt of sea, is described as the territorial sea. This sovereignty extends to the air space over the territorial sea as well as to its bed and subsoil.
The sovereignty over the territorial sea is exercised subject to the United Nations Convention of Law on the Sea (UNCLOS) and to other rules of international law.

Value.label: archipelagic
Value.definition: The baseline for measuring the breadth of the territorial sea is the straight baseline joining the outermost points of the outermost islands and drying reefs of the archipelago.
SOURCE Article 47 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Value.label: normal
Value.definition: The normal baseline for measuring the breadth of the territorial sea is the low-water line along the coast as marked on large-scale charts officially recognized by the coastal State.
SOURCE Article 5 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Value.label: straight
Value.definition: The baseline for measuring the breadth of the territorial sea is the straight baseline established by joining the appropriate points.
SOURCE Article 7 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

Value.label: singular
Value.definition: EXAMPLES Danube (English), Lac du Bourget (French), Praha (Czech), Nederland (Dutch).

Value.label: official
Value.definition: Name in current use and officially approved or established by legislation.

Value.label: standardised
Value.definition: Name in current use and accepted or recommended by a body assigned advisory function and/or power of decision in matters of toponymy.

Value.label: historical
Value.definition: Historical name not in current use.

Value.label: other
Value.definition: Current, but not official, nor approved name.

Value.label: endonym
Value.definition: Name for a geographical feature in an official or well-established language occurring in that area where the feature is situated.

Value.label: exonym
Value.definition: Name used in a specific language for a geographical feature situated outside the area where that language is widely spoken, and differing in form from the respective endonym(s) in the area where the geographical feature is situated.

Value.label: administrativeUnit
Value.definition: Units of administration, dividing areas where Member States have and/or exercise jurisdictional rights, for local, regional and national governance, separated by administrative boundaries.
SOURCE Definition of Annex I theme, INSPIRE Directive [Regulation 1205/2008/EC].
- Administrative unit within a country such as state, province, region, municipality.

Value.label: building
Value.definition: SOURCE Definition of Annex III theme [INSPIRE Directive].
NOTE This definition of building should be refined from future works on the specification of the INSPIRE annex III theme BUILDINGS.
- Public buildings such as theatre, museum, library;
- Religious buildings such as church, mosque, synagogue;

Value.label: hydrography
Value.definition: Hydrographic elements, including marine areas and all other water bodies and items related to them, including river basins and sub-basins.
SOURCE Definition of Annex I theme HYDROGRAPHY, INSPIRE Directive [Regulation 1205/2008/EC].
NOTE For the usage with Geographical names this includes named places in seas and oceans.
- Marine areas and parts of them such as sea, gulf, sea strait, sea channel, fjord, sea bay;
- Inland water areas such as lake, reservoir, pond, lake strait, lake bay;
- Watercourses such as river, stream, rapids, waterfall, canal;
- Other hydrographic features such as glacier, snowfield, geyser, spring, fountain, well.

Value.label: landcover
Value.definition: Physical and biological cover of the earth's surface including artificial surfaces, agricultural areas, forests, (semi-)natural areas, wetlands, water bodies.
SOURCE Definition of Annex III theme, INSPIRE Directive.
- Low vegetation areas such as thicket;
- Wetlands such as marsh, swamp, bog;
- Agricultural areas such as arable land, cultivated field, pasture;
- Other terrain cover features such as desert, badland, lava field, remarkable tree.

Value.label: landform
Value.definition: - Land elevations such as mountain range, mountain, mountainside, fell, highland, hill, ridge, peak;
- Land depressions such as plain, valley, pass, gorge;
- Coastal land formations such as peninsula, headland, cape, delta, beach, cliff;
- Other landforms such as cave, devil's churn, stone.

Value.label: protectedSite
Value.definition: Area designated or managed within a framework of international, Community and Member States' legislation to achieve specific conservation objectives.
SOURCE Definition of Annex I theme, INSPIRE Directive [Regulation 1205/2008/EC].

Value.label: transportNetwork
Value.definition: Road, rail, air and water transport networks and related infrastructure. Includes links between different networks.
SOURCE Definition of Annex I theme, INSPIRE Directive [Regulation 1205/2008/EC].
- Air transport structures and facilities such as airport, heliport;
- Water transport structures and facilities such as harbour, dock, pier, ferry line;
- Rail transport structures and facilities such as railway station, railway bridge, railway tunnel;
- Road transport structures and facilities such as bus station, highway, road, street, road bridge, road tunnel.

Value.label: other
Value.definition: A spatial object not included in the other types of the code list.

Value.label: boundary
Value.definition: Node used to connect different networks.

NOTE Can be used to connect cross border networks or adjacent networks together. Differs from source / outlet in that in the real world there is an adjacent link that is not present in the dataset supplied.

Value.label: flowConstriction
Value.definition: A network node unrelated to the network topology per se, but associated with a hydrographic point of interest or facility, or a man-made object, that affects the network flow.
NOTE May include dams, widenings and other obstructions in the watercourse.

Value.label: flowRegulation
Value.definition: A network node unrelated to the network topology per se, but associated with a hydrographic point of interest or facility, or a man-made object, that regulates the network flow.
NOTE May include weirs, pumping stations and hydro power plants as well as abstraction and discharge into / from the watercourse.

Value.label: junction
Value.definition: Node where three or more links are coincident.
NOTE Includes all nodes at which different watercourses or watercourse branches merge into one (confluence) and where watercourses fork and divide (bifurcations).

Value.label: outlet
Value.definition: Ending node of a series of interconnected links.
NOTE Does not have an downstream output link. Includes sinks and watercourse mouths.

Value.label: source
Value.definition: Starting node of a series of interconnected links.
NOTE Does not have an upstream input link. Includes springs and seeps.

Value.label: clay
Value.definition: A stiff tenacious fine-grained earth consisting mainly of hydrated aluminosilicates, which become more plastic when water is added and can be moulded and dried.

Value.label: mud
Value.definition: Soft wet soil, sand, dust, and/or other earthy matter.

Value.label: sand
Value.definition: Granular material consisting of small eroded fragments of (mainly siliceous) rocks, finer than gravel and larger than a coarse silt grain.

Value.label: shingle
Value.definition: Small, loose, rounded waterworn pebbles, especially as accumulated on a seashore.

Value.label: stone
Value.definition: Pieces of rock or mineral substance (other than metal) of definite form and size, usually artificially shaped, and used for some special purpose.

Value.label: natural
Value.definition: An indication that a spatial object is natural.

Value.label: manMade
Value.definition: An indication that a spatial object is man-made.

Value.label: aqueduct
Value.definition: A pipe or artificial channel that is designed to transport water from a remote source, usually by gravity, for freshwater supply, agricultural, and/or industrial use.

Value.label: bridge
Value.definition: A structure that connects two locations and provides for the passage of a transportation route over a terrain obstacle.
EXAMPLE 1 (Transportation route) A road or a railway.
EXAMPLE 2 (Terrain obstacle) A waterbody, a gully, and/or a road.

Value.label: culvert
Value.definition: An enclosed channel for carrying a watercourse under a route.
EXAMPLE 1 (Watercourse carried in an enclosed channel) A stream, a sewer, or a drain.
EXAMPLE 2 (Route over a culvert) A road, a railway, or an embankment.

Value.label: siphon
Value.definition: A pipe used for conveying liquid from one level to a lower level, using the liquid pressure differential to force a column of the liquid up to a higher level before it falls to the outlet.

Value.label: equinoctialSpringLowWater
Value.definition: The level of low water springs near the time of an equinox.

Value.label: higherHighWater
Value.definition: The highest of the high waters (or single high water) of any specified tidal day due to the declination A1 effects of the moon and sun.

Value.label: higherHighWaterLargeTide
Value.definition: The average of the highest high waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.

Value.label: highestAstronomicalTide
Value.definition: The highest tidal level, which can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.

Value.label: highestHighWater
Value.definition: The highest water level observed at a location.

Value.label: highWater
Value.definition: The highest level reached at a location by the water surface in one tidal cycle.
NOTE When used on inland waters it is generally defined as a level that the daily mean water level exceeds less than 5 percent of the time.

Value.label: highWaterSprings
Value.definition: An arbitrary level, approximating that of mean high water springs.

Value.label: indianSpringHighWater
Value.definition: A tidal surface datum approximating the level of the mean of the higher high water at spring tides.
NOTE This tidal datum approximates the highest water level observed at a location and is usually above that of the higher high water at spring tides.

Value.label: indianSpringLowWater
Value.definition: A tidal surface datum approximating the level of the mean of the lower low water at spring tides.
NOTE This tidal datum approximates the lowest water level observed at a location and is usually below that of the lower low water at spring tides.

Value.label: localDatum
Value.definition: An arbitrary datum defined by an authority of a local harbour, from which levels and tidal heights are measured by that authority.

Value.label: lowerLowWater
Value.definition: The lowest of the low waters (or single low water) of any specified tidal day due to the declination A1 effects of the moon and sun.

Value.label: lowerLowWaterLargeTide
Value.definition: The average of the lowest low waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.

Value.label: lowestAstronomicalTide
Value.definition: The lowest tide level that can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.

Value.label: lowestLowWater
Value.definition: An arbitrary level conforming to the lowest tide observed at a location, or somewhat lower.

Value.label: lowestLowWaterSprings
Value.definition: An arbitrary level conforming to the lowest water level observed at a location at spring tides during a period shorter than 19 years.

Value.label: lowWater
Value.definition: An approximation of mean low water adopted as the reference level for a limited region, irrespective of better determinations later.

NOTE Used mostly in harbour and river engineering. Used in inland waters. It is generally defined as a level which the daily mean water level would fall below less than 5 percent of the time and by no more than 0.2 metres during the navigation season. A single level surface is usually chosen as the low water datum for a whole lake. On a river, low water datum is a sloping surface, which approximates the surface of the river at a low state.

Value.label: lowWaterDatum
Value.definition: An approximation of mean low water that has been adopted as a standard reference for a limited area.
NOTE 1 It is retained for an indefinite period regardless of the fact that it may differ slightly from a better determination of mean low water from a subsequent series of observations.
NOTE 2 Used primarily for river and harbor engineering purposes.

Value.label: lowWaterSprings
Value.definition: A level approximating that of mean low water springs.

Value.label: meanHigherHighWater
Value.definition: The average height of higher high waters at a location over a 19-year period.

Value.label: meanHigherHighWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of higher high water at spring tides at a location.

Value.label: meanHigherLowWater
Value.definition: The average of the higher low water height of each tidal day observed over a National Tidal Datum Epoch.
NOTE For stations with shorter series, comparison of simultaneous observations with a control tide station is made in order to derive the equivalent datum of the National Tidal Datum Epoch.

Value.label: meanHighWater
Value.definition: The average height of all high waters at a location over a 19-year period.

Value.label: meanHighWaterNeaps
Value.definition: The average height of the high waters of the neap tide.

Value.label: meanHighWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of the high waters of spring tides.

Value.label: meanLowerHighWater
Value.definition: The average of the lower high water height of each tidal day observed over a National Tidal Datum Epoch.
NOTE For stations with shorter series, comparison of simultaneous observations with a control tide station is made in order to derive the equivalent datum of the National Tidal Datum Epoch.

Value.label: meanLowerLowWater
Value.definition: The average height of the lower low waters at a location over a 19-year period.

Value.label: meanLowerLowWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of lower low water at spring tides at a location.

Value.label: meanLowWater
Value.definition: The average height of all low waters at a location over a 19-year period.

Value.label: meanLowWaterNeaps
Value.definition: The average height of the low waters of the neap tide.

Value.label: meanLowWaterSprings
Value.definition: The average height of the low waters of spring tides.

Value.label: meanSeaLevel
Value.definition: The average height of the sea at a tide station measured from a fixed predetermined reference level.
NOTE Usually determined from hourly height readings, for all stages of the tide, over a 19-year period.

Value.label: meanTideLevel
Value.definition: The arithmetic mean of mean high water and mean low water.

Value.label: meanWaterLevel
Value.definition: The average of all hourly water levels over the available period of record.

Value.label: nearlyHighestHighWater
Value.definition: An arbitrary level approximating the highest water level observed at a location, usually equivalent to the high water springs.

Value.label: nearlyLowestLowWater
Value.definition: A level approximating the lowest water level observed at a location, usually equivalent to Indian spring low water.

Value.label: tropicHigherHighWater
Value.definition: The highest of the high waters (or single high water) of the tides occurring semimonthly when the effect of the Moon's maximum declination is greatest.
NOTE At these times there is a tendency for an increase in the diurnal range.

Value.label: tropicLowerLowWater
Value.definition: The lowest of the low waters (or single low water) of the tides occurring semimonthly when the effect of the Moon's maximum declination is greatest.
NOTE At these times there is a tendency for an increase in the diurnal range.

Value.label: dry
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing infrequently, generally only during and/or immediately after heavy precipitation.
NOTE The waterbody is often vegetated (for example: with shrubs); such a streambed in the Southwestern United States is termed a 'derramadero'.

Value.label: ephemeral
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing during and immediately after precipitation.

Value.label: intermittent
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing for part of the year.

Value.label: perennial
Value.definition: Filled and/or flowing continuously throughout the year as its bed lies below the water table.

Value.label: natura2000
Value.definition: The Protected Site has a designation under either the Habitat Directive (92/43/EEC) or the Birds Directive (79/409/EEC).

Value.label: emeraldNetwork
Value.definition: The Protected Site has a designation under the Emerald Network.
The Emerald Network is an ecological network to conserve wild flora and fauna and their natural habitats in Europe.

Value.label: ramsar
Value.definition: The Protected Site has a designation under the Ramsar Convention.
The Ramsar Convention provides the framework for national action and international cooperation for the conservation and wise use of wetlands and their resources.

Value.label: UNESCOWorldHeritage
Value.definition: The Protected Site has a designation under UNESCO World Heritage Convention.

Value.label: IUCN
Value.definition: The Protected Site has a classification using the International Union for Conservation of Nature classification scheme.

Value.label: UNESCOManAndBiosphereProgramme
Value.definition: The Protected Site has a designation under UNESCO Man and Biosphere programme.

Value.label: nationalMonumentsRecord
Value.definition: The Protected Site has a classification using the National Monuments Record classification scheme.

Value.label: natureConservation
Value.definition: The Protected Site is protected for the maintenance of biological diversity.

Value.label: archaeological
Value.definition: The Protected Site is protected for the maintenance of archaeological heritage.

Value.label: cultural
Value.definition: The Protected Site is protected for the maintenance of cultural heritage.

Value.label: ecological
Value.definition: The Protected Site is protected for the maintenance of ecological stability.

Value.label: landscape
Value.definition: The Protected Site is protected for the maintenance of landscape characteristics.

Value.label: environment
Value.definition: The Protected Site is protected for the maintenance of environmental stability.

Value.label: geological
Value.definition: The Protected Site is protected for the maintenance of geological characteristics.

Value.label: cabinCableCar
Value.definition: A cableway transport whose vehicles consist on a suspended cabin to carry groups of people and/or goods inside it from one destination to another.

Value.label: chairLift
Value.definition: A cableway transport whose vehicles consist on suspended chairs to carry individuals or groups of people from one destination to another via a steel cable or rope which is looped around two points.
It Is traditionally found on mountains or steep hills but is being used more and more in amusement parks.

Value.label: skiTow
Value.definition: A cableway transport is a mechanised system for pulling skiers and snowboarders uphill.
Passengers grab hold of the rope and are pulled along while standing on their skis or snowboards and sliding up the hill. Synonyms: rope tow, handle tow.

Value.label: conventional
Value.definition: Conventional navigation route: An air route which does neither use Area Navigation (RNAV) nor TACAN navigation for air traffic services.

DEFINITION Definition of Area Navigation (RNAV): A method of navigation which permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path within the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids or within the limits of the capability of selfcontained aids, or a combination of both [ICAO].

Value.label: RNAV
Value.definition: Area navigation route: An air route which uses Area Navigation (RNAV) for air traffic services.

DEFINTION Area Navigation (RNAV): A method of navigation which permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path within the coverage of station-referenced navigation aids or within the limits of the capability of selfcontained aids, or a combination of both [ICAO].

Value.label: TACAN
Value.definition: TACAN route: An air route which uses TACAN Navigation for air traffic services.

DEFINITION TACAN Navigation: A method of navigation which permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path within the coverage of station-referenced Tactical Air Navigation Beacon (TACAN) navigation aids.

Value.label: NDB-MKR
Value.definition: Non-Directional Radio Beacon and Marker Beacon.

Value.label: ATS
Value.definition: ATS Route as described in ICAO Annex 11.

Value.label: NAT
Value.definition: North Atlantic Track (part of Organized Track System).

Value.label: reservedForMilitary
Value.definition: The air network object is exclusively for military use.

Value.label: temporalRestrictions
Value.definition: The temporal restrictions apply to the use of the air network object.

Value.label: FATO
Value.definition: Final Approach and Take Off Area for helicopters.

Value.label: asphalt
Value.definition: Surface made of an asphalt layer.

Value.label: concrete
Value.definition: Surface made of a concrete layer.

Value.label: grass
Value.definition: Surface consisting on a grass layer.

Value.label: end
Value.definition: Physical end of a runway direction.

Value.label: mid
Value.definition: The mid point of the runway.

Value.label: start
Value.definition: Physical start of a runway direction.

Value.label: domesticNational
Value.definition: Aerodrome serving domestic national air traffic services.

Value.label: domesticRegional
Value.definition: Aerodrome serving domestic regional air traffic services.

Value.label: international
Value.definition: Aerodrome serving international air traffic services.

Value.label: ATZ
Value.definition: Airport Traffic Zone. Airspace of defined dimensions established around an airport for the protection of airport traffic. Description: ICAO Recognized.
NOTE An ATZ usually is set up from the lower limit of a Control Zone (CTR) to the surface.

Value.label: CTA
Value.definition: Control area. A controlled airspace extending upwards from a specified limit above the earth. Description: ICAO Recognized.

NOTE 1 A CTA could exist in the vicinity of a single airport to manage a busy air traffic area in order to provide protection to aircraft climbing out from the airport. As such it is a smaller version of a Terminal Maneuvering Area or Terminal Control Area (TMA), equivalent to it but serving only to one airport.
NOTE 2 Standard Intrument Departure (SID) routes usually ends at the upper limit of a TMA or CTA, where the air route phase starts.

Value.label: CTR
Value.definition: Control zone. A controlled airspace extending upwards from the surface of the earth to a specified upper limit. Description: ICAO Recognized.

NOTE It is normally extended from the surface to a specified upper limit, set up to protect air traffic operating to and from that airport. A CTR usually is set up from the upper limit of an Aerodrome Traffic Zone (ATZ).

Value.label: D
Value.definition: Danger area. Airspace of defined dimensions within which activities dangerous to the flight of aircraft may exist at specified times. Description: ICAO Recognized.

NOTE It is defined as a constraint airspace area to be avoided if possible, which could be dangerous for navigation of air traffic services and could be crossed only by specific routes and specific flight levels defined by the Defence Authority.

Value.label: FIR
Value.definition: Flight information region. Airspace of defined dimensions within which flight information service and alerting service are provided. Description: ICAO Recognized. Might, for example, be used if service provided by more than one unit.
NOTE 1 A FIR is an airspace region in which information, management and search-and-rescue services are provided by an air navigation service provider.

NOTE 2 Any portion of the atmosphere belongs to some specific FIR, except from some cases. Small countries could have only a single FIR; bigger ones could have some regional FIRs. The division among different countries is done by international agreement through ICAO.

Value.label: P
Value.definition: Prohibited area. Airspace of defined dimensions, above the land areas or territorial waters of a State, within which the flight of aircraft is prohibited. Description: ICAO Recognized.
NOTE It is defined as a constraint airspace area to be avoided, in which navigation of air traffic services is forbidden for high security reasons.

Value.label: R
Value.definition: Restricted area. Airspace of defined dimensions, above the land areas or territorial waters of a State, within which the flight of aircraft is restricted in accordance with certain specified conditions. Description: ICAO Recognized.
NOTE It is defined as a constraint airspace area in which navigation of air traffic services is restricted and could only be crossed temporarily with authorisation and at specific flight levels.

Value.label: TMA
Value.definition: Terminal control area. Control area normally established at the confluence of ATS routes in the vicinity of one or more major aerodromes. Description: Non-ICAO Recognized. Mainly used in Europe under the Flexible Use of Airspace concept.

NOTE 1 It is normally extended from a lower to an upper limit, set up at an area of confluence of busy airways in the vicinity of one or more major airports to protect traffic climbing out from and descending into the airports.
NOTE 2 As such it is a larger version of a Control Area (CTA). Standard Intrument Departure (SID) routes usually ends at the upper limit of a TMA or CTA, where the air route phase starts.

Value.label: UIR
Value.definition: Upper flight information region (UIR). An upper airspace of defined dimensions within which flight information service and alerting service are provided. Description: Non-ICAO Recognized. Each state determines its definition for upper airspace.

Value.label: junction
Value.definition: A railway node where the railway network have a mechanism consisting on a railroad track with two movable rails and the necessary connections, which let vehicles turn from one track to another.

Value.label: levelCrossing
Value.definition: A railway node where the railway network is a crossed by a road at the same level.

Value.label: pseudoNode
Value.definition: A railway node which represents a point where one or more attributes of the railway links connected to it change their value, or a point necessary to describe the geometry of the network.

Value.label: railwayEnd
Value.definition: A railway node where the railway starts or ends. The railway network is interrupted at this point.

Value.label: railwayStop
Value.definition: A place in the railway network where trains stop to load/unload cargo or to let passengers get on and off the train.

Value.label: average
Value.definition: The number of tracks is the average value for a given part of the railway network.

Value.label: maximum
Value.definition: The number of tracks is the maximum value for a given part of the railway network.

Value.label: minimum
Value.definition: The number of tracks is the minimum value for a given part of the railway network.

Value.label: broad
Value.definition: The nominal track gauge property is broader than the standard one.

Value.label: standard
Value.definition: The nominal track gauge property is equal to the European standard (1435 millimetres).

Value.label: narrow
Value.definition: The nominal track gauge property is narrower than the standard one.

Value.label: notApplicable
Value.definition: The definition of a nominal track gauge property is not applicable to the type of railway transport.

Value.label: cargo
Value.definition: The use of railway is exclusively for cargo operations.

Value.label: carShuttle
Value.definition: The use of railway is exclusively to perform car shuttle transport.

Value.label: mixed
Value.definition: The use of railway is mixed. It is used to transport passengers and cargo..

Value.label: passengers
Value.definition: The use of railway is exclusively to transport passengers[TWG-TN].

Value.label: cogRailway
Value.definition: A railway transport which allows the vehicles to operate on steep gradients, consisting on a railway provided with a toothed rack rail (usually between the running rails) where vehicles are fitted with one or more cog wheels or pinions that mesh with this rack rail.
Synonyms: cog railway, pens and rails railway, rack-and-pinion railway or rack railway.

Value.label: funicular
Value.definition: A railway transport consisting on a cable attached to a vehicle on rails which moves them up and down a very steep slope, where it is possible the ascending and descending vehicles counterbalancing each other.
Synonyms: funicular railway, incline, inclined railway, inclined plane or cliff railway.

Value.label: magneticLevitation
Value.definition: A railway transport based on a single rail which acts as guideway of a vehicle and support it by means of a magnetic levitation mechanism.

Value.label: metro
Value.definition: An urban railway transport system used in large urban areas, which runs on a separate track from other transport systems, is usually electrically powered and in some cases runs under ground. .

Value.label: monorail
Value.definition: A railway transport based on a single rail which acts either as its only support and guideway.

Value.label: suspendedRail
Value.definition: A railway transport based on a single rail, acting either as support and guideway, from which a vehicle is suspended to move along the railway.

Value.label: train
Value.definition: A railway transport usually consisting on two parallel rails on which a powered-vehicle or train machine pulls a connected series of vehicles to move them along the railway in order to transport freight or passengers from one destination to another.

Value.label: tramway
Value.definition: A railway transport system used in urban areas, which often runs at street level, sharing road space with motor traffic and pedestrians. Tramways are usually electrically powered.

Value.label: other
Value.definition: Ferry carries others forms of transport than passengers, cars, trucks or trains.

Value.label: junctionFork
Value.definition: Infrastructure elements where the one vessel traffic flow crosses another vessel traffic flow or points where vessel traffic flows divide or come together.

Value.label: lockComplex
Value.definition: Lock or group of locks, intended for raising and lowering boats between stretches of water of different levels on river and canal waterways.

Value.label: movableBridge
Value.definition: Bridge that can be raised or turned to allow the passage of ships.

Value.label: terminal
Value.definition: The location where goods are transhipped.
NOTE A terminal forms a link between the various transport modes, of which shipping is one. A terminal therefore has waterside loading and unloading places [COMPRIS].

Value.label: turningBasin
Value.definition: A place where a canal or narrow waterway is widened to allow boats to turn around.

Value.label: shipLift
Value.definition: A machine for transporting boats between water bodies at two different elevations, which is used as an alternative to the canal locks..
NOTE Synonyms: boat lift, lift lock.

Value.label: I
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class I, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: II
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class II, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: III
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class III, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: IV
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class IV, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: Va
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class Va, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: Vb
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class Vb, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: VIa
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class VIa, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: VIb
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class VIb, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: VIc
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class VIc, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: VII
Value.definition: Inland waterway belonging to CEMT-class VII, defined by the European Conference of Ministers of Transport, Resolution No.92/2 - Table 1.

Value.label: forbiddenLegally
Value.definition: Access to the transport element is forbidden by law.

Value.label: physicallyImpossible
Value.definition: Access to the transport element is physically impossible due to the presence of barriers or other physical obstacles.

Value.label: private
Value.definition: Access to the transport element is restricted because it is privately owned.

Value.label: publicAccess
Value.definition: The transport element is open to public access.

Value.label: seasonal
Value.definition: Access to the transport element depends on the season.

Value.label: toll
Value.definition: Access to the transport element is subject to toll.

Value.label: maximumDoubleAxleWeight
Value.definition: The maximum weight per double axle of a vehicle allowed at a transport element.
NOTE This value applies to wheeled vehicles only.

Value.label: maximumHeight
Value.definition: The maximum height of a vehicle which can pass under another object .

Value.label: maximumLength
Value.definition: The maximum length of a vehicle allowed at a transport element.

Value.label: maximumSingleAxleWeight
Value.definition: The maximum weight per single axle of a vehicle allowed at a transport element.
NOTE This value applies to wheeled vehicles only.

Value.label: maximumTotalWeight
Value.definition: The maximum total weight of a vehicle allowed at a transport element.

Value.label: maximumTripleAxleWeight
Value.definition: The maximum weight per triple axle of a vehicle allowed at a transport element.
NOTE This value applies to wheeled vehicles only.

Value.label: maximumWidth
Value.definition: The maximum width of a vehicle allowed on a transport element.

Value.label: air
Value.definition: The transport network consists of transport by air.

Value.label: cable
Value.definition: The transport network consists of transport by cable.

Value.label: rail
Value.definition: The transport network consists of transport by rail.

Value.label: road
Value.definition: The transport network consists of transport by road.

Value.label: water
Value.definition: The transport network consists of transport by water.

Value.label: inNationalPark
Value.definition: Speed limit restriction inside national park.

Value.label: nearRailroadCrossing
Value.definition: Speed limit restriction near rail road crossing.

Value.label: trafficCalmingArea
Value.definition: Speed limit restriction in traffic calming area.

Value.label: busStation
Value.definition: The road service is a bus stop.

Value.label: parking
Value.definition: The road service areea is a parking facility.

Value.label: restArea
Value.definition: The road service is a rest area.

Value.label: toll
Value.definition: Area that provides toll services such as ticket dispensers or toll payment services.

Value.label: carWithTrailer
Value.definition: A passenger car with an attached trailer.

Value.label: deliveryTruck
Value.definition: A truck vehicle of relatively small size, whose principal use is for delivery of goods and materials.

Value.label: emergencyVehicle
Value.definition: A vehicle engaged in emergency response, included but not limited to police, ambulance and fire.

Value.label: employeeVehicle
Value.definition: A vehicle operated by an employee of an organization that is used within that organization's ground.

Value.label: facilityVehicle
Value.definition: A vehicle dedicated to a localized area within a private or restricted estate.
EXAMPLE Facilities roads within an airport or theme park.

Value.label: farmVehicle
Value.definition: Vehicle commonly associated with farming activities.

Value.label: highOccupancyVehicle
Value.definition: Vehicle populated with a number of occupants corresponding to (or exceeding) the specified minimum number of passengers.

Value.label: lightRail
Value.definition: Train-like transport vehicle limited to a rail network within a limited area.
NOTE Does not include heavy rail lines.

Value.label: mailVehicle
Value.definition: A vehicle that collects, carries or delivers mail.

Value.label: militaryVehicle
Value.definition: Vehicle authorized by a military authority.

Value.label: moped
Value.definition: Two or three wheeled vehicle equipped with internal combustion engine, with size less than 50 cc and maximum speed that does not exceed 45 km/h (28mph).

Value.label: motorcycle
Value.definition: Two or three wheeled vehicle equipped with internal combustion engine, with size more than 50 cc and maximum speed that does exceed 45 km/h (28mph).

Value.label: passengerCar
Value.definition: A small vehicle designed for private transport of people.

Value.label: privateBus
Value.definition: A vehicle designed for transport of large groups of people, privately owned or chartered.

Value.label: publicBus
Value.definition: A vehicle designed for transport of large groups of people that is generally charterized by published routes and schedules.

Value.label: residentialVehicle
Value.definition: A vehicle whose owner is resident (or a guest) of particular street or town area.

Value.label: schoolBus
Value.definition: Vehicle operated on behalf of a school to transport students.

Value.label: snowChainEquippedVehicle
Value.definition: Any vehicle equipped with snow chains.

Value.label: tanker
Value.definition: A truck with more than two axels used to transport liquid loads in bulk.

Value.label: taxi
Value.definition: A vehicle licensed for hire usually fitted with a meter.

Value.label: transportTruck
Value.definition: A truck vehicle for long range transport of goods.

Value.label: trolleyBus
Value.definition: A bus-like mass transport vehicle hooked up to an electrical network for power supply.

Value.label: vehicleForDisabledPerson
Value.definition: A vehicle with supporting identification that designates a vehicle for disabled persons.

Value.label: vehicleWithOtherDangerousLoad
Value.definition: Vehicle transporting dangerous cargo, other than explosive or waterpollution loads.

Value.label: mainRoad
Value.definition: The most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: firstClass
Value.definition: The second most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: secondClass
Value.definition: The third most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: thirdClass
Value.definition: The fourth most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: fourthClass
Value.definition: The fifth most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: fifthClass
Value.definition: The sixth most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: sixthClass
Value.definition: The seventh most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: seventhClass
Value.definition: The eighth most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: eighthClass
Value.definition: The ninth most important roads in a given network.

Value.label: ninthClass
Value.definition: The least important roads in a given network.
NOTE The farthest ways in the forest road network. It has no regular maintenance. [NVDB] [Euroroads].

Value.label: fog
Value.definition: Speed applies when fog is present.

Value.label: ice
Value.definition: Speed applies when ice is present.

Value.label: rain
Value.definition: Speed applies when rain is present.

Value.label: smog
Value.definition: Speed applies when a certain amount of smog is present.

Value.label: snow
Value.definition: Speed applies when snow is present.

Value.label: bicycleRoad
Value.definition: Road where bicycles are the only vehicles allowed.

Value.label: dualCarriageway
Value.definition: Road with physically separated carriageways regardless of the number of lanes, which is not a motorway or a freeway.

Value.label: enclosedTrafficArea
Value.definition: Area with no internal structure of legally defined driving directions. At least two roads are connected to the area.

Value.label: entranceOrExitCarPark
Value.definition: Road specially designed to enter or to leave a parking area.

Value.label: entranceOrExitService
Value.definition: Road used only to enter or to leave a service.

Value.label: freeway
Value.definition: Road having no single level crossings with other roads.
NOTE This means that connections with other roads consist of slip roads.

Value.label: motorway
Value.definition: Road permitted for motorized vehicles only in combination with a prescribed minimum speed. It has two or more mostly physically separated carriageways and no single level-crossings.

Value.label: pedestrianZone
Value.definition: Area with a road network which is especially designed for use by pedestrians.

NOTE Pedestrian zones are usually located in urban areas. Except for emergency vehicles and for delivery vehicles during certain hours no traffic is allowed on the road network elements which are located inside the zone.

Value.label: roundabout
Value.definition: Road which forms a ring on which traffic travelling in only one direction is allowed.
NOTE The Road elements which make up a roundabout are connected to one another and they form exactly one ring.

Value.label: serviceRoad
Value.definition: Road running parallel to and connecting to a road with a relatively high connectivity function, which is especially designed to enable access from the connecting roads to roads with a low connectivity function in its vicinity.
NOTE Generally, service roads have the same name as the higher class road it runs parallel to and are only divided from it by small constructions like walkways, traffic islands etc.

Value.label: singleCarriageway
Value.definition: Road where the traffic is not separated by any physical object.
NOTE All roads without separate carriageways are considered as roads with a single carriageway.

Value.label: slipRoad
Value.definition: Road especially designed to enter or leave a road.

Value.label: tractor
Value.definition: Arranged road only usable for a tractor (farm vehicle or forest machine) or terrain vehicle (a vehicle with higher ground clearance, big wheels and 4 wheel drive).

Value.label: trafficSquare
Value.definition: Area (partly) enclosed by roads which is used for non-traffic purposes and which is not a roundabout.

Value.label: walkway
Value.definition: Road reserved for pedestrian use and closed for regular vehicular use by a physically barrier.
NOTE Occasional use by (emergency) services may occur.

Value.label: maximum
Value.definition: The number of lanes is the maximum value for a given part of the road network.

Value.label: minimum
Value.definition: The number of lanes is the minimum value for a given part of the road network.

Value.label: average
Value.definition: The number of lanes is the average value for a given part of the road network.

Value.label: enclosedTrafficArea
Value.definition: The road node is situated inside and/or represents an enclosed traffic area.
A traffic area is an area with no internal structure of legally defined driving directions. At least two roads are connected to the area..

Value.label: junction
Value.definition: Three or more road links intersect at the road node.

Value.label: levelCrossing
Value.definition: A railway crosses a road on the same level at the position of the road node.

Value.label: pseudoNode
Value.definition: Exactly two road links connect to the road node.

Value.label: roadEnd
Value.definition: Only one road link connects to the road node. It signifies the end of a road.

Value.label: roundabout
Value.definition: The road node represents or is a part of a roundabout.

Value.label: trafficSquare
Value.definition: The road node is situated inside and/or represents a traffic square.
A traffic square is an area (partly) enclosed by roads which is used for non-traffic purposes and which is not a roundabout.

Value.label: roadServiceArea
Value.definition: Surface annexed to a road and devoted to offer particular services for it.
EXAMPLES Gas station, rest area, toll area.

Value.label: fixedTrafficSign
Value.definition: Source is a fixed traffic sign (site specific administrative order, explicit speed limit).

Value.label: regulation
Value.definition: Source is a regulation (national regulation, rule or 'implicit speed limit').

Value.label: variableTrafficSign
Value.definition: Source is a variable traffic sign.

Value.label: maximum
Value.definition: Speed limit is a maximum value

Value.label: minimum
Value.definition: Speed limit is a minimum value

Value.label: recommendedMaximum
Value.definition: Speed limit is a recommended maximum value

Value.label: recommendedMinimum
Value.definition: Speed limit is a recommended minimum value

Value.label: carriageway
Value.definition: The part of a road which is reserved for traffic.

Value.label: pavedSurface
Value.definition: The part of the road which is paved.

Value.label: paved
Value.definition: Road with a hard paved surface.

Value.label: master
Value.definition: Contour at a vertical distance which is multiple to the equidistance parameter (corresponding to a certain multiple of the normal contour vertical interval) associated with the nominal scale.

Value.label: ordinary
Value.definition: Contour at the equidistance parameter (corresponding to the normal contour vertical interval) associated with the nominal scale, and which is not a master contour.

Value.label: auxiliary
Value.definition: A supplementary contour – not corresponding to the normal contour vertical interval – estimated or interpolated from surrounding contours, used in areas where there is insufficient height information for elevation mapping purposes or to control the creation of a digital elevation model.
NOTE This term is equivalent to the value 'intermediate' used in some Member States.

Value.label: airQualityManagementZone
Value.definition: Part of the territory of a Member State, as delimited by that Member State for the purposes of air quality assessment and management.

Value.label: noiseRestrictionZone
Value.definition: An area delimited by a competent authority to manage and mitigate noise pollution.
This includes agglomerations and quiet areas (in agglomerations and open country) as defined in the Environmental Noise Directive (2002/49/EC).
NOTE: Noise restriction zones may also be defined to manage noise exposure relating to transport (airports, roads, rail), entertainment venues, recreational activities, construction, etc.

Value.label: animalHealthRestrictionZone
Value.definition: Restriction zones established for the control and eradiation of notifiable animal diseases
EXAMPLE: Avian Influenze Restriction Zones (Council Directive 2005/94/EC).

Value.label: prospectingAndMiningPermitArea
Value.definition: The area on which the prospection or extraction of any mineral has been authorised and for which that right or permit is granted.

EXAMPLE: Directive 94/22/EC on conditions for granting and using authorisations for the prospection, exploration and production of hydrocarbons, stipulates that the limits of the geographical areas covered by an authorisation and the duration of that authorisation must be determined in proportion to what is justified in terms of the best possible exercise of the activities from an economic and technical point of view.

Value.label: regulatedFairwayAtSeaOrLargeInlandWater
Value.definition: Regulated navigation areas port-to-port established in accordance with Decision 884/2004/EC of the European Parliament and Council of 29 April 2004 amending Decision No 1692/96/EC on Community guidelines for the development of the trans - European transport network to organise sailing traffic, prevent accident and pollution.

Value.label: restrictedZonesAroundContaminatedSites
Value.definition: Zones established to protect human, plant and animal health and control movement and development within a contaminated site.
EXAMPLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant Exclusion Zone which was established to evacuate the local population and to prevent people from entering the heavily contaminated territory.
EXAMPLE: Zone established around an area suffering from soil contamination to restrict development and protect human health.

Value.label: areaForDumpingOfWaste
Value.definition: Area affected by uncontrolled disposal of waste as defined in Waste Framework Directive (2006/12/EC) Art 4.

Value.label: coastalZoneManagementArea
Value.definition: Area in which "integrated coastal zone management" takes place.

DEFINITION: "Integrated coastal zone management” is a dynamic process for the sustainable management and use of coastal zones, taking into account at the same time the fragility of coastal ecosystems and landscapes, the diversity of activities and uses, their interactions, the maritime orientation of certain activities and uses and their impact on both the marine and land parts.
SOURCE: Protocol on Integrated Coastal Zone Management in the Mediterranean - signed in Madrid on 20-21 January 2008.

Value.label: drinkingWaterProtectionArea
Value.definition: Area in which waste water leakage, use of fertilizer or pesticides, or establishment of waste disposal sites are prohibited.
EXAMPLE: From Directive 80/778, relating to the quality of water intended for human consumption.

According to the article 8 providing that Member States shall take all the necessary measures to ensure that any substances used in the preparation of water for human consumption do not remain in concentrations higher than the maximum admissible.

Value.label: nitrateVulnerableZone
Value.definition: Areas of land which drain into polluted or threatened waters and which contribute to nitrate pollution.
SOURCE: Art 3 of Council Directive 91/676/EEC of 12 December 1991 concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources.

Value.label: marineRegion
Value.definition: Marine regions and their subregions are sea regions designated for the purpose of assessment, management and regulation.
For each Marine Region a marine strategy shall be developed and implemented to maintain and improve good environmental status.

Value.label: riverBasinDistrict
Value.definition: Area of land and sea, made up of one or more neighbouring river basins together with their associated groundwaters and coastal waters, identified under Article 3(1) as the main unit for management of river basins.
SOURCE: Art 2 (15) of DIRECTIVE 2000/60/EC OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for Community action in the field of water policy.
NOTE: A river basin district can either be an international or national river basin district or a sub unit of management.

NOTE 2: The relatedZone role should be used to link river basin districts. For example, a national river basin district should include a relatedZone attribute linking it to the international river basin district.

Value.label: bathingWaters
Value.definition: Coastal waters or inland waters (rivers, lakes) explicitly authorised, or not prohibited for recreational bathing by large numbers of people.
NOTE: Bathing waters are set limits for physical, chemical and microbiological parameters to ensuring clean bathing waters to protect public health and the environment.

Value.label: floodManagementUnit
Value.definition: Coastal areas or individual river basins assigned as the unit of management established for the assessment and management of flood risk.
These are coastal areas or individual river basins assigned as a unit of management different from those assigned pursuant to Article 3(1) of Directive 2000/60/EC.

Value.label: sensitiveArea
Value.definition: Sensitive areas are surface waters (freshwater, estuaries and coastal waters) that require protection against eutrophication.
SOURCE: Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive (91/271/EEC).

Value.label: designatedWaters
Value.definition: Marine, coastal or surface waters designated by Member States as needing protection or improvement in order to support fish life.
Member States are required to define designated waters to protect freshwater fish and shellfish by the Fisheries Directive (2006/44/EC) and Shellfish Waters Directive (2006/113/EEC).

Value.label: plantHealthProtectionZone
Value.definition: Protection zone within which protective measures are established against the introduction of organisms harmful to plants or plant products and against their spread.

Value.label: international
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the international level.

Value.label: national
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the national level.

Value.label: regional
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the regional level.

Value.label: local
Value.definition: This is a region classification on the local level.

Value.label: natura2000AndEmeraldBio-geographicalRegion
Value.definition: A set of code lists to be used to define the Natura 2000 and Emerald network Biogeographical regions.

Value.label: environmentalStratification
Value.definition: A set of code lists to be used to define the Environmental Stratification.

Value.label: naturalVegetation
Value.definition: A set of code lists to be used to define the natural vegetation.

Value.label: marineStrategyFrameworkDirective
Value.definition: A set of codes to be used for the Marine Stategy Framework Diretive region classification.

Value.label: lowestAstronomicalTide
Value.definition: The lowest tide level that can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.

Value.label: meanSeaLevel
Value.definition: The average height of the sea at a tide station measured from a fixed predetermined reference level.
Ordnance Datum, often used as a reference point for defining vertical heights, uses the mean Sea Level as its reference point and therefore is also included within this value.

Value.label: seafloor
Value.definition: The bottom of a sea or ocean.

Value.label: marineStrategyFrameworkDirective
Value.definition: Marine Strategy Framework Directive, Annex III table 3.

Value.label: congruent
Value.definition: This value expresses that the local type is conceptually the same as its related Pan-European type.

Value.label: excludes
Value.definition: This value expresses that the Pan-European habitat type is conceptually no subtype of its related local type.

Value.label: includedIn
Value.definition: This value expresses that the local type is conceptually a subtype of its related Pan-European type.

Value.label: includes
Value.definition: This value expresses that the Pan-European habitat type is conceptually a subtype of its related local type.

Value.label: overlaps
Value.definition: This value expresses that between the local and its related Pan-European type there is a certain overlap according to their definition and that differs from the other values of this list.

Value.label: modelling
Value.definition: The area has been computed according to a model.

Value.label: indirectDetermination
Value.definition: The area has been defined by interpretation of available data and/or information.

Value.label: common
Value.definition: The species is common in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: rare
Value.definition: The species is rare in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: veryRare
Value.definition: The species is very rare in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: present
Value.definition: The species is present in the SpeciesDistributionUnit.

Value.label: absent
Value.definition: The species has been looked for but not found in the species distribution unit.

Value.label: wintering
Value.definition: Uses the site during the winter.

Value.label: reproducing
Value.definition: Uses the site to raise young (e.g. breeding, nesting).

Value.label: concentration
Value.definition: Site used for staging or roosting or migration stop/over or for moulting outside the breeding grounds and excluding wintering.

Value.label: permanent
Value.definition: To be found throughout the year on the site (non-migratory species or plant, resident population of migratory species).

Value.label: cultivated
Value.definition: Species is cultivated, not occurring in the wild.

Value.label: introducedEstablished
Value.definition: Species has been introduced and is reproducing with stable populations.

Value.label: introducedImpermanent
Value.definition: Species has been introduced, but has no stable, reproducing populations.

Value.label: naturallyImpermanent
Value.definition: Species is naturally introduced (by natural migration), but has no stable, reproducing populations.

Value.label: probablyExtinct
Value.definition: Species has not been observed by recent surveys, but no positive proof of extinction is possible.

Value.label: re-introducedOrTranslocated
Value.definition: An extinct population of formerly native species has been re-introduced as a nature conservation measure.

Value.label: includedIn
Value.definition: The concept of the localSpeciesName is included in the concept of the referenceSpeciesName.

Value.label: includes
Value.definition: The concept of the localSpeciesName is includes the concept of the referenceSpeciesName.

Value.label: overlaps
